titleStmt.title: Rimage Workflow for Making Archival Discs
titleStmt.author: Greg Murray (gpm2a@virginia.edu), Digital Library Production Services

publicationStmt.publisher: Digital Library Production Services, University of Virginia Library

argument.p: This document describes the workflow for making archival DVDs using the Rimage systems at Digital Library Production Services (DLPS), University of Virginia Library. It is intended for use by internal DLPS staff.
Note: This documentation pertains to version 6.5 of the Rimage OfficeNet software.

div1.head: Quick Start
div1.p: The basic steps for making archival DVDs are:

list.item: Identify the files to be archived

div1.p: The details for these steps are:

list.item: Identify the files to be archived and copy them to any disk accessible to the Rimage PC (typically the E: drive).
Load the input bin with new recordable DVDs (or CDs). (On the Desktop 1500, the input bin is the one with the three prongs to hold the discs. On the 2000i, the input bin is the left bin.)

Check the current setting for media type:
Open the Rimage System Manager (Start → All Programs → Rimage → Rimage System Manager).
Click the main Settings... button near the picture of the Rimage 2000i (or the picture of the Desktop 1500, as the case may be).
In the Bins/Media tab, under the Media: section, check the Media type setting. It will be set to either DVDR or CDR.
If the setting already corresponds to the type of discs you will be burning, then just click OK. If it doesn't, you must set it to the type of media you will be using:
Click Cancel to close the settings window.
Pause the Production Server by clicking its "pause" button (looks like a VCR pause button with the || symbol).
Click the main Settings... button near the picture of the Rimage 2000i (or the picture of the Desktop 1500, as the case may be).
In the Bins/Media tab, under the Media: section, change the Media type setting to DVDR or CDR as appropriate.
Click OK to save the settings and close the settings window.
Click the "resume server" button for the Production Server (looks like a VCR play button with a green triangle).

Open a command-line window and run the rimage.pl Perl script, providing the paths to the directories to be burned to DVD:
perl &scriptPath; E:\myFiles
where myFiles is a directory on disk E: containing files and/or subdirectories to be burned to DVD.
Open the command-line window using Start → Programs → Accessories → Command Prompt. If you use Start → Run... to run the Perl script, the window will close automatically as soon as the script is finished running, and you will not be able to see any final status or error messages that may have been displayed.
After all discs have been burned successfully, copy the log files to the DLPS workspace (DLPSadministrative/03archivaldisks/rawfiles), then import the log files into the DLPS tracking system.

div2.head: Rimage system
div2.p: The Rimage system (Rimage is the name of the manufacturer; see rimage.com) is a combination of hardware and software that facilitates transferring large sets of data to DVD or CD media. (It also has an auto-loader feature for reading large sets of data from existing DVDs or CDs, but that's a different workflow.)

The Rimage system produces a disc by first creating a disc image (a single file containing all of the data to be burned to disc) and then burning that image to the media (DVD or CD disc) as many times as necessary to produce the number of copies requested. The process of creating the disc image is referred to as "imaging" and is handled by the Imaging Server. The process of burning the image to one or more discs is referred to as "production" and is handled by the Production Server.

div2.head: rimage.pl
div2.p: The Perl script rimage.pl does the work of determining how many files will fit on a disc and how many discs are required to encompass the entire set of files. It is not necessary to make that determination yourself, arrange the files into any particular directory structure, etc.

The only argument required by rimage.pl is the path to the directory containing the files to be burned to DVD. So the simplest way to run &script; would be:
perl &scriptPath; E:\myFiles
where myFiles is a directory on disk E: containing files and/or subdirectories to be burned to DVD. Alternatively, the script allows more than one directory to be specified:
perl &scriptPath; E:\fileset1 E:\fileset2 E:\fileset3
The script has several switches to further control how the discs are made:

row.cell: Base ID to use when determining disc ID
Off; defaults to the current date as a 6-digit date in yymmdd format
Number of copies to make of each disc
2 (The default is 2 because it is standard DLPS practice to burn 2 copies of each disc and store them in separate locations.)
Keep disc image (.img) files after producing the discs
Off; default is to delete each disc image when burning from that image is complete
Informal name of label template: allowed values are "DLPS", "FKL", "TBRC" and "THDL"
"DLPS" — uses the standard DLPS label template
Type of disc media: allowed values are "DVD" and "CD"
DVD (In practice, DLPS does not use CDs for archival storage.)
Report how many discs will be needed and what their IDs will be, but do not create any editlists, log files, etc. and do not actually burn any discs
Display all status messages (in addition to error messages)
Only create disc images; do not produce discs
Off; create disc images and produce discs
Only produce discs from existing disc images; do not create disc images
Off; create disc images and produce discs from those images

div2.p:
On the command line, the switches must appear before the path argument(s). For example:
perl &scriptPath; -c 1 -v E:\fileset1
tells the script to produce only one copy of the data (one set of discs) and to display all status messages.

When using the -P (production only) switch, the path argument should be the path to the directory containing the existing disc images to use (not the path to the original data, as would normally be required).

div2.head: Log files
div2.p: The rimage.pl script generates log files that record important information about each disc, including a list of the files contained on the disc. These log files are originally written to the C: drive of the Rimage PC, but they need to be copied to the DLPS workspace for long-term storage and also imported into the DLPS tracking system for searching.

list.item: In the DLPS workspace, go to directory DLPSadministrative/03archivaldisks/rawfiles. If there is a directory indicating the project for which these discs were created, use that directory. Otherwise, create a new directory, and name it in a way that indicates the project for which these discs were created.

Copy the log files for the discs produced (there will be one log file for each disc) from C:\Rimage\Logs on the Rimage PC to DLPSadministrative/03archivaldisks/rawfiles/[subdirectory] where [subdirectory] is the directory from the preceding step.
Log into the DLPS tracking system. In the navigation bar along the left, under Archival Discs click Import Rimage log file.

Using this form, import each log file. Use the Browse... button to locate each log file to be imported. In the Project label field, enter the name of the directory (from the preceding step) from which you are importing.

Under Archival Discs, click Search for archival discs. Use the first part of the disc ID (which is a six-digit date in yymmdd format) to get a list of the discs corresponding to the log files you just imported. Make sure all log files have been imported.
